awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Research experiences for Deaf Students in Systems Biology and Molecular Signaling- How Cells and Organisms make Decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, TN, will support the training of 10 students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2019- 2021. An interdisciplinary faculty team in the biological, physical, and computational sciences will mentor students in projects that address the global question: "How do cells and organisms perceive their environment and make life or death decisions?" Students will use stae-of-the-art molecular, genetic, genomic, and systems biology/bioinformatics techniques to investigate how organisms across the biological kingdom sense and adapt to a changing environment. Besides independent research projects, professional development workshops on science communication, responsible research/scientific inquiry, and career options in STEM will be held.  As part of a larger Summer REU Scholars community,  students will present their work at a campus-wide science/engineering symposium.

A total of 30 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program.  This program will specifically target Deaf and hard-of-hearing (D/HH) students, a population underrepresented in STEM careers nationally. In addition to D/HH students, hearing students interested in research training as well as American Sign Language (ASL) are encouraged to apply.  Students will be incorporated into a heterogeneous environment of hearing and D/HH individuals that stresses modern scientific training, research competency, and independence and communication.  In addition, to stimulate the participation of young K-12 D/HH students in STEM careers, REU students will also participate in program outreach through lab visits with students from regional Tennessee D/HH high schools.
A common web-based assessment tool used by REU Site programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students will be tracked after the program in order to determine their career paths. Students will be asked to respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system. Additional program assessment will determine impact on 1. Scientific knowledge development; 2. Communication and integration; and 3. Career development prospects . More program information is available at http://bcmb.utk.edu/reu, or can be obtained by contacting the PI (Dr. Daniel Roberts at drobert2@utk.edu) or the co-PI (Dr. David Smith at dsmit147@utk.edu).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The foundational focus of this Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) project was to promote greater participation and development of Deaf students in STEM research at the forefront of modern molecular and cellular biosciences, bioinformatics, and systems level biology, areas that are leading to new discoveries in health, agriculture and innovation. The REU site allowed participants to engage in innovative research under the mentorship of outstanding science and engineering faculty at the University of Tennessee, Knoxville, with access to state-of-the-art facilities and resources that are typically not available at their home institutions. Students also participated in an integrated professional training program with lectures, workshops, and hands-on exercises in the design, conduct, and analysis of their experiments, and communication of their research findings. Most importantly, given the focus of a highly specialized and underrepresented student population, workshops and career panels tailored to address the needs of Deaf/hard of hearing (D/hh) students in the pursuit of post-secondary STEM careers were held.  Research training in molecular signaling and systems biology, complemented with professional skills workshops, provided these members of the future science workforce with a foundation in modern molecular and cellular bioscience inquiry and scientific communication.

Intellectual Merit

Organisms across all biological kingdoms possess the common challenge of sensing and adapting to a changing and hostile environment.  Complex arrays of molecules assembled into genetic and metabolic networks have evolved to perceive external stimuli and trigger the appropriate adaptive response that determines cell or organism survival.  The unifying strength of this research training program for undergraduate cellular and molecular biology students was the common focus on the central question and intellectual theme: “How Cells and Organisms make Life and Death Decisions in a Changing Environment.”

With the rich data sets now available from genomic and bioinformatic resources, and the power of computational and mathematical modeling, we are beginning to understand and predict how molecules and networks give rise to emergent properties and behaviors of cells and organisms.   This is the emerging area of “systems-level biology” which is at the forefront of modern cellular and molecular biology and it is poised to transform medicine and agriculture.

To provide student trainees training in modern quantitative systems approaches in molecular and cellular biology, we assembled a multidisciplinary team of faculty research mentors across three colleges at the University of Tennessee with broad expertise spanning biophysical, biochemical, genetic, microbial, plant science, neuroscience, mathematic/computational biology, and engineering disciplines. During the three years of the program, 35 students (3 training cohorts) engaged in an intensive ten-week REU research projects integrating molecular, genetic, genomic, and systems level approaches to investigate the strategies through which model organisms across all biological kingdoms (with projects in animal, plant and microbial model systems) sense and adapt to a changing environment. Projects ranged from field work and soil sampling/metagenomics related to pathogen and environmental microbiology to neurological analysis mouse maternal behavior in a genetic autistic model to engineering nanofabrication of environmental biological sensors.

Broader Impacts

In alignment with NSF's strategic goal of broadening participation for underrepresented group in science and engineering, this program specifically targeted D/hh student participation. D/hh students remain drastically underrepresented in STEM disciplines and STEM workplaces, largely due to marginalization and isolation in traditional hearing educational environments due to differing communication needs (i.e., American Sign Language literacy), lack of adequate academic preparation in K-12 settings, a lack of STEM role models who are D/hh, and the lack of familiarity of hearing research mentors with Deaf culture and D/hh needs. This program was specifically designed to address this deficit by  recruiting and training D/hh students (29/35 students recruited to the program [77%] identified as D/hh). Another pressing need for D/hh researchers is the availability of scientifically literate ASL interpreters. To address this need and to work towards greater integration of D/hh and hearing research students, 23% of the students trained in the program were hearing students with a combined interest in molecular and cellular biology and ASL/Deaf culture.
